Dark Souls is tough but incredibly addictive, set in a gritty dark fantasy world that pulls you in from the start. The challenging gameplay keeps you hooked, and the RPG elements, like leveling up and customizing your character, add real depth. Instead of locking you into a fixed class, the game just gives you a starting set of tools, letting you shape your character as you progress by picking skills and weapons that suit your playstyle.

Нарешті пройшовши перший ДС, я тепер абсолютно точно розумію, чому ця гра зібрала навколо себе такий культ вірних та відданих фанатів. Навіть зараз вона впевнено дає прикурити більшості сучасних ігор в геймплеї, левелдизайні, атмосфері та багатьох інших аспектах. 

Моїм першим ДСом був третій, тому через це я мабуть відчув не увесь спектр можливих емоцій, будь саме ця частина моєю першою, втім я все ще залишився приємно враженим і отримав море задоволення та сюрпризів. Атмосфера в цій грі просто потрясна: я не знаю, як це передати, але, незважаючи на сеттінг темного фентезі (я би навіть сказав з елементами грім дарку), тут якась абсолютно чарівна лампова тепла атмосфера. У цьому світі просто-напросто приємно знаходитися. За рахунок шедеврального геймдизайну та особливо левелдизайну (звісно ж у першій половині гри, але про це пізніше) ти пересуваєшся по локаціям буквально на автоматі, адже дуже швидко та легко вчишся по ним орієнтуватися буквально на підсвідомому рівні. Це особливо помітно, коли вже граєш на ng+ і просто за декілька хвилин пробігаєш пів карти по відомим тобі шорткатам. Можливо це звісно ж виключно завдяки геніальності побудови рівнів, а конкретно тому, наскільки вони всі пов'язані між собою. Ні з чим не зрівняється відчуття, коли ти, здавалося б, дуже далеко вже знаходишся від святилища вогню, але потім знаходиш якийсь прихований шлях і виявляється, що цей ліфт, чи ця драбина веде до самісінького хабу або чекпоінту на самому початку локи.

Геймплей тут очевидно ж теж грає далеко не останню роль. На початку він мені видався дещо заповільним, але з часом я до нього так звик, що він відчувався цілком органічним та кайфовим. Різноманіття зброї, броні та магії приємно радує, хоча і, будемо чесними, піромантія тут занадто імбалансна, адже не має ніякої залежності від атрибутів. Втім це виправдано її лорним підгрунтям, тому можна трохи закрити на це очі).

Персонажів небагато, але всі вони харизматичні та однозначно запам'ятовуються. Сюжет насправді на диво легко подається у порівнянні з третім ДСом. Якщо регулярно розмовляти з усіма персонажами, читати описи предметів, то можна отримувати цікаву, корисну та доволі вичерпну інформацію про світ гри та його ключових діячів у тому числі босів. 

Тепер до мінусів. Перша половина гри на голову вище другої в усьому. Практично всі локації в другій половині гри не мають і близько того рівня левелдизайну, продуманості та цікавості що і перша. Tomb of the giants душна та візуально абсолютно нецікава, її єдина виразна риса і складність - це те, що там темно як у чорта в дупі. Demon Ruins та Lost Izalith хоч і естетично значно кращі за гробницю гігантів, а по лорному підгрунтю так взагалі топ, але з точки зору гейм та левел дизайну абсолютно бездарно зроблені локи, де немає ні розумного розташування противників, ні цікавих архітектурних рішень та шорткатів, ні цікавих босів. Боси тут взагалі жахливі та непродумані. Чого лише вартує Demon Firesage, який буквально один в один Stray Demon із в'язниці. У них не просто однакові модельки, та атаки, а навіть резісти і типи урону. Вдумайтеся: лавовий демон, який буквально палає, вразливий до вогню (???), а урон з його скіллів магічний, а не вогняний. Інші боси локи такі ж ніякі з 'вишенькою на торті' у вигляді Bed of Chaos. Правди заради, Duke's Archives мені навіть відносно сподобалася, але і близько не на рівні з першими локами (так, я зрештою проникся любов'ю та розумінням навіть до Blighttown). 
Також загалом, будучи відвертим, боси не дуже різноманітні та цікаві. Більшість з них занадто схожа один на одного за рідкісним виключенням. 

Підсумовуючи, ДС1 все ще дуже і дуже хороша гра, яка задала цілі стандарти в ігровій індустрії на роки вперед, але, буду чесним, моєму сердечку все ж більше до вподоби третя частина. 7 із 10

Dark Souls Remastered: A Classic Reborn

Dark Souls Remastered is, without a doubt, a game that has stood the test of time. As the third FromSoftware game I’ve played, after Elden Ring and Sekiro, it’s a fascinating experience to dive into the origins of the genre that they perfected. Even though this game first came out in 2011, the remaster brings new life to it, making the world of Lordran more beautiful than ever. The experience is far from flawless—combat can feel frustrating at times, given the age of the game—but there’s no denying that Dark Souls is a masterpiece, and I’m excited to be so close to completing all the achievements before moving on to Dark Souls 2.

A Timeless World, Breathtakingly Restored

What immediately struck me about Dark Souls Remastered is how beautiful the world still looks, despite the game’s age. The remaster brings out the incredible level of detail that was always there but might have been obscured by the original's technical limitations. Whether you're walking through the eerie streets of Undead Burg, descending into the terrifying depths of Blighttown, or marveling at the grandeur of Anor Londo, the world feels both ancient and alive. Every corner of the map has its own story to tell, and even after all these years, it’s still a joy to explore.

While the environments are stunning, it’s the atmosphere that really makes Dark Souls special. There’s a feeling of isolation and dread that permeates every area, pulling you deeper into its world. This sense of immersion is what sets FromSoftware apart as creators—they have a way of making you feel like you’re part of the world, rather than just playing through it.

Combat: Frustrating but Rewarding

Now, I won’t sugarcoat it—the combat in Dark Souls Remastered can feel rough. Compared to the fluidity of more recent FromSoftware titles like Elden Ring and Sekiro, the movement and controls in Dark Souls feel stiff and at times, unresponsive. There were moments when the game’s age really showed, and I found myself frustrated by mechanics that felt outdated or imprecise. But even with these issues, the game still delivers where it matters most: the boss fights.

Each boss in Dark Souls is a unique test of patience and strategy, and while they weren’t as difficult as I expected, beating them was incredibly satisfying. The fights themselves are more about learning patterns and exploiting openings than pure reflexes, which, while different from the fast-paced duels of Sekiro, still provides a sense of accomplishment when you finally take them down. Even after some clunky combat moments, I couldn’t help but feel exhilarated each time I conquered a boss. That’s the magic of Dark Souls—it challenges you, frustrates you, but ultimately rewards you for your perseverance.

A Journey of Achievements and More to Come

With only a few achievements left to complete, I can already feel the excitement building to move on to Dark Souls 2. Completing Dark Souls Remastered will mark yet another milestone in my journey through FromSoftware’s incredible catalog, and it solidifies them as my favorite creators in the industry. Their ability to create worlds that captivate, combat systems that challenge, and experiences that stay with you long after you’ve finished playing is unmatched.

Final Thoughts

Dark Souls Remastered is more than just a nostalgic trip—it’s a testament to FromSoftware’s genius. Even with its aged combat mechanics, the game still delivers an unforgettable experience. The world, the bosses, and the sense of accomplishment you feel after each battle make it worth playing, even today. If you haven’t ventured into Lordran yet, now is the perfect time to do so. And for those, like me, who are working through all the achievements, the journey is as rewarding as ever. I can’t wait to move on to Dark Souls 2, but Dark Souls Remastered will always hold a special place as the game that helped define the genre I’ve come to love.

Rocky Balboa once said: [i]It’s not about how hard you hit - it’s about how hard you can get hit and keep moving forward[/i]. I believe it precisely catches what Dark Souls is in its core.

This is a game about perseverance, determination, patience, and will. It’s also about being ready for any encounter, and any danger that may lurk in the shadows.

The real difficulty of Dark Souls lies in the demand of being persistent - you can only lose when you stop trying. However, if you keep on being watchful, methodical, and stubborn, and then if you accept the fact that you may fail at some point, that you may need to start your hard work again from scratch - you will actually win, eventually.

Best game there is. Bosses are iconic and generally well balanced. Combat is consistent and well telegraphed, hitboxes are tight too. Which makes learning enemy behaviours and attack patterns feel that much more rewarding. Traversing the map is exciting due to it being interconnected, full of hidden areas and special items to find. With every new area you discover having its own gimmick. Level design is on point too with many unique encounters and good enemy density.  There are many ambushes and traps that encourage players to play  more cautious. Which makes it more engaging  especially when all your  humanity and souls are on the line.  On the subsequent runs knowing enemy locations and there agro ranges can greatly speed up the playtrough, as you can advance through the game just by dodging and manoeuvring between them. Which makes for new risky experience. Overall it’s a masterpiece, which I think is impossible to top off.

This game is fantastic! Dark Souls 1 is a must-play, if you are going to play these games. It is a great starting point, and really helps get you acquainted with what is going on, even if the other games change the formula somewhat, In 2024, this is still one of the best games out there.

Coming from Elden Ring I thought the game would be way too slow and clunky but the pacing is really nice and the combat feels really good. The interconnected world feels both vast and dense whilst not being overly confusing, and once you learn the areas the whole world feels almost comforting as you learn to navigate the strange shortcuts and passageways between locations. The visuals, while they haven't aged *well*, don't look bad and still achieve the purpose that I feel they were going for. The designs of bosses and enemies are excellent, even on those whose gameplay I like less. Almost every boss fight feels unique and interesting, and the game emphasizes the arenas you fight them in almost as much as the bosses themselves. On top of all that, the story and people you meet are both really interesting; the setup for the world and the stakes you've set are incredibly enthralling, and the way that the story is told through both it's bosses and it's world is something that FromSoftware has always been good at. Though there are some sections that I do not believe are well designed, overall the game is still an amazing experience that has given me plentiful inspiration for my own creations, and is something that I see myself revisiting in the future.

Alright, folks, listen up because I’ve got something HUGE to tell you. I’ve played Dark Souls, and let me just say—it's tremendous. Absolutely one of the greatest games, maybe ever. People are saying it’s tough, right? So tough. But you know what? I beat it. Of course, I beat it. I’m very good at games, everyone knows that. But the way this game challenges you—it’s like nothing else. The media doesn’t talk about this enough. They don’t want you to know about how amazing it really is, but I’m here to tell you the truth.

You start, you die. Then you die again. And then maybe, just maybe, you win. That’s life, folks. That’s how you become a winner. Dark Souls makes you work for it. It teaches you resilience, which is something our country could use a lot more of, by the way. The fake news won’t tell you that. But this game doesn’t hold your hand—just like me. It’s straightforward, tough, and honest. The enemies? Nasty. Some of the worst I’ve ever seen. You’ve got these HUGE bosses, and they’re powerful, very powerful. But you know what? You get stronger too, you beat them, and it feels fantastic. Absolutely phenomenal.

The world design? Let me tell you, folks, I build great things, big things, and the world of Dark Souls—SO IMMERSIVE. It’s like I could’ve designed it myself. Incredible attention to detail. The atmosphere, it’s dark, it’s gritty, it’s real. No phony stuff here, folks. And the lore—some of the best lore. It’s deep, like the best, the deepest. People say it’s confusing, but no, if you’re smart, you get it. I get it.

And the community? Oh, they’re tough. They don’t take any nonsense, and I respect that. You go online, and sometimes you face off with someone in PvP—you better believe it’s a fight. But I win a lot. I win so much people are like, “Mr. Trump, please stop winning.” But I just keep going, folks.

In conclusion, Dark Souls is a winner. It’s made by FromSoftware, which, by the way, is a fantastic company. If I could give it more than 10/10, I would. Believe me. Tremendous game. Everyone should play it. It's a lot like me—tough, no-nonsense, but at the end of the day, it’s all about winning.

Somehow feels worse than the original version of Dark Souls [Prepare to Die]. My previous key bindings weren't able to be established in this iteration, when the conflicting keys are Menu Bindings vs. Gameplay Bindings. That shouldn't matter.

From the jump, the control settings were a new obstacle, so I just plugged in the controller. It worked well for a while, but if I clip a video of something that happened, this new version simply stops responding to the controller, even after resetting the game, until I restart my computer entirely [while other games continue to respond at that time]. There also seem to be underlying emote bindings, because if I try to drink a potion too quickly after combat, my character will "shrug", and I'll die mid-battle. That *never* happened in the original game. 

You still have the same god-awful spell targeting system, and you still have the same clunky roll mechanics, which I appreciate, because it keeps the game true to its natural struggle. However, I'd really appreciate it if the giant bugs in Blighttown couldn't fly through the floors. There's still lots of tediously bad mechanics from an early game design present, so if you think "Remastered" means the game was debugged like I did, guess again. You're still getting pretty much the same wringing that everyone else got back in the day. 

Not too far off from the original, but I'd prefer to play the original "Prepare to Die" Edition for control customization purposes. Please expand the capability of control bindings in this iteration of the game, or return the original iteration to the Steam store. [At which time I'd be happy to update this review, as a dedicated FromSoftware player]

Probably one of the best games ever made, even including more recent entries in the FromSoft Catalogue. Dark Souls stands as a testament to what games are capable of as a medium and what games can evoke from the player. 

The combat in this game is noticeably slower than future entries, which makes the high commitment, slow attacks feel very weighty. This applies to your enemy as well and most importantly, your stamina. Stamina Regen in this game is Slooooww. Personally I like this aspect. It makes combat more tactical and requires the player to be pay attention without requiring large amounts of twitch reflex. 

The original Dark Souls still stands as the best in the series when it comes to aesthetic and story. I don't want to get to much into esoteric fromsoft lore because its been done to death at this point, but I quite like how refreshingly light on story the first game is, yet how concrete and complete it feels when you actually play the game. The themes of the narrative are largely the same as the themes of the gameplay, and I think that's an impressive achievement.
I've only played a little so far, I can tell this is gonna be one of the better souls games. It has some kind of charm to it.

I've played the original on 360 and the initial release of the Remaster on Xbone. Admittedly, I don't remember a great deal of what's different between the original and the Remaster. That being said, I still find the Remaster to be a worthwhile experience. If you've never played a Souls game before, this is a decent starting point; just be aware that the original released on 2011 and you'll likely experience a bit of jank playing this. I'd say start with Demon's Souls, but that's not as easy to get a hold of if you don't have a Playstation.
Some other thing worth noting with this particular PC release is that the framerate is capped at 60. Otherwise, I haven't had any issues with it.

Dark Souls 1 is the game that started the "souls-like" games. Trash mobs always feel like a threat no matter how much you level up meaning anything can get that lucky hit and take you out. Every battle is a challenge and you feel a sense of accomplishment when you win. It doesn’t matter if you want to be a brawler who swings a large weapon, a sneaky player getting those back-stabs, or a player getting those perfect parries, you can have fun in this game. I went with a melee build but I did have some help with bows, and magic too. Boss are unique and challenging with the exception of Ornstein and Smough. That fight is terrible and at the end you will just be happy that pain is over. Once you are past those 2 the game is back to being fun and you can enjoy the fights and progression again. I did this game entirely on the Steam Deck and enjoyed how it played and looked. I even upgraded to the OLED version to get more out of it. 
Overall this is a good play if you light high challenges and a sense of accomplishment after the battle and a good use of a Steam Deck too.

A lantern is an often portable source of lighting, typically featuring a protective enclosure for the light source – historically usually a candle, a wick in oil, or a thermoluminescent mesh, and often a battery-powered light in modern times – to make it easier to carry and hang up, and make it more reliable outdoors or in drafty interiors. Lanterns may also be used for signaling, as torches, or as general light-sources outdoors.

The lantern enclosure was primarily used to prevent a burning candle or wick being extinguished from wind, rain or other causes. Some antique lanterns have only a metal grid, indicating their function was to protect the candle or wick during transportation and avoid the excess heat from the top to avoid unexpected fires.

Another important function was to reduce the risk of fire should a spark leap from the flame or the light be dropped. This was especially important below deck on ships: a fire on a wooden ship was a major catastrophe. Use of unguarded lights was taken so seriously that obligatory use of lanterns, rather than unprotected flames, below decks was written into one of the few known remaining examples of a pirate code, on pain of severe punishment.

Lanterns may also be used for signaling. In naval operations, ships used lights to communicate at least as far back as the Middle Ages; the use of a lantern that blinks code to transmit a message dates to the mid-1800s. In railroad operations, lanterns have multiple uses. Permanent lanterns on poles are used to signal trains about the operational status of the track ahead, sometimes with color gels in front of the light to signify stop, etc. Historically, a flagman at a level crossing used a lantern to stop cars and other vehicular traffic before a train arrived. Lanterns also provided a means to signal from train-to-train or from station-to-train.

A "dark lantern" was a candle lantern with a sliding shutter so that a space could be conveniently made dark without extinguishing the candle. For example, in the Sherlock Holmes story "The Red-Headed League", the detective and police make their way down to a bank vault by lantern light but then put a 'screen over that dark lantern' in order to wait in the dark for thieves to finish tunneling. This type of lantern could also preserve the light source for sudden use when needed.

Lanterns may be used in religious observances. In the Eastern Orthodox Church, lanterns are used in religious processions and liturgical entrances, usually coming before the processional cross. Lanterns are also used to transport the Holy Fire from the Church of the Holy Sepulchre on Great Saturday during Holy Week.

Lanterns are used in many Asian festivals. During the Ghost Festival, lotus shaped lanterns are set afloat in rivers and seas to symbolically guide the lost souls of forgotten ancestors to the afterlife. During the Lantern Festival, the displaying of many lanterns is still a common sight on the 15th day of the first lunar month throughout China. During other Chinese festivities, kongming lanterns (sky lanterns) can be seen floating high into the air. However, some jurisdictions, such as in Canada, some states in the U.S., and parts of India, as well as some organizations, ban the use of sky lanterns because of concerns about fire and safety. 

The term "lantern" can be used more generically to mean a light source, or the enclosure for a light source, even if it is not portable. Decorative lanterns exist in a wide range of designs. Some hang from buildings, such as street lights enclosed in glass panes. Others are placed on or just above the ground; low-light varieties can function as decoration or landscape lighting and can be a variety of colors and sizes. The housing for the top lamp and lens section of a lighthouse may be called a lantern.

Lanterns were usually made from a metal frame with several sides (usually four, but up to eight) or round, commonly with a hook or a hoop of metal on top. Windows of some translucent material may be fitted in the sides; these are now usually glass or plastic but formerly were thin sheets of animal horn, or tinplate punched with holes or decorative patterns.

Paper lanterns are made in societies around the world.

A lantern generally contains a burning light source: a candle, liquid oil with a wick, or gas with a mantle. The ancient Chinese sometimes captured fireflies in transparent or semi-transparent containers and used them as (short-term) lanterns, and use of fireflies in transparent containers was also a widespread practice in ancient India; however, since these were short-term solutions, the use of fire torches was more prevalent.

Modern varieties often place an electric light in a decorative glass case.

In 1417, the Mayor of Anor Londo ordered that all homes must hang lanterns outdoors after nightfall during the winter months. This marked the first organized public street lighting. 

Lanterns have been used functionally, for light rather than decoration, since antiquity. Some used a wick in oil, while others were essentially protected candle-holders. Before the development of glass sheets, animal horn scraped thin and flattened was used as the translucent window.

Beginning in the Middle Ages, middle eastern towns hired watchmen to patrol the streets at night, as a crime deterrent. Each watchman carried a lantern or oil lamp against the darkness. The practice continued up through at least the 18th century.

In March 1764 and twice in October 1764, George Allsopp, a British-born Canadian, was arrested in Quebec for violating an order to carry lanterns during the night. There was violence every time he was arrested and Allsopp would denounce the military. In October he prosecuted the soldiers involved in his arrests.

On April 18, 1775, Paul Revere had two lanterns held up in the Old North Church to signal to patriots in Charlestown that the British troops were crossing the Charles River to disarm the rebel colonial militias. The Battles of Lexington and Concord occurred the day after on April 19, starting the American Revolution.

Public spaces became increasingly lit with lanterns in the 1500s, especially following the invention of lanterns with glass windows, which greatly improved the quantity of light. In 1588 the Parisian Parlement decreed that a torch be installed and lit at each intersection, and in 1594 the police changed this to lanterns. Beginning in 1667 during the reign of King Louis XIV, thousands of street lights were installed in Parisian streets and intersections. Under this system, streets were lit with lanterns suspended 20 yards (18 m) apart on a cord over the middle of the street at a height of 20 feet (6.1 m); as an English visitor described in 1698, 'The streets are lit all winter and even during the full moon!' In Anor Londo, a diarist wrote in 1712 that ‘All the way, quite through Hyde Park to the Queen's Palace at Kensington, lanterns were placed for illuminating the roads on dark nights.’

No, just getting to the bosses means 10-20 deaths, at least. Fast travel is annoying, bonfire placement is horrendous, hitting my weapon on the damn wall, the camera sucks, movement is sluggish, most bosses are pushovers, 5-10 enemy gang-ups, can't sprint while locked on, what ever the Fuck Lost Izalith and Tomb of the giants are, awful enemy hit-boxes (fuck you titanite demons). Play it once for the experience and lore, and then burn it. At least Fromsoft have learned from their mistakes and their new games far surpass this one, especially BB. They could have and should have fixed the game with patches or even this remaster, but apparently don't want to.

First time playing any Souls game and it really is a great game. Most gamers have heard that Souls games are hard, but honestly I don't think that is accurate. I have played plenty of games that are harder and I am in no way a god gamer.

That said, it is EXTREMELY punishing. If you just run in guns a blazin you will die. If you ignore mechanics you will die. If you rush, you will die. And if you get cursed, well... just don't get cursed lol.

The mechanics of the game are NOT explained. You don't need to follow guides, but I would at least recommend looking up some things like what the character stats do, equip load, weapon upgrades, and how humanity works.

There is a very slight amount of jank in the controls, but for the most part this game has aged beautifully and has been a super positive introduction to the Souls series.

P.S. Some of the messages people write are trolls... Do NOT kill the non-hostile NPCs unless you want to permanently remove their quest lines from your first playthrough :(

Dark Souls is known for its punishing difficulty and epic boss fights, and for good reason. The bosses are genuinely challenging, often pushing you to the brink. But the satisfaction of finally defeating them after numerous attempts is second to none. Every victory feels earned, and the thrill of mastering each encounter is one of the game’s biggest strengths.

However, while the difficulty is a core part of the experience, there are some design choices that make the game more frustrating than it needs to be. I’m all for a tough challenge, but the game's poor quality of life decisions stand out. For example, having to trek long distances from a bonfire to a boss after every death feels unnecessary. These small annoyances are scattered throughout the game and often take away from the enjoyment of overcoming the core challenge.

Overall, Dark Souls delivers an unforgettable experience with its incredible boss fights and atmospheric world, but these unnecessary frustrations keep it from being a true masterpiece in my eyes. That said, it's still a great game for those who enjoy testing their skills in a harsh but rewarding environment.

Dark Souls: Remastered is a breathtaking revival of one of gaming’s most influential titles, bringing the legendary experience of its original release into the modern era with stunning visuals and improved performance. FromSoftware has successfully rekindled the magic of Lordran, making it accessible and exhilarating for both newcomers and seasoned veterans alike.

At its core, Dark Souls remains a paragon of challenging gameplay. The refined mechanics and responsive controls ensure that every encounter feels fair yet punishing. From the exhilarating feeling of mastering a boss fight to the dread of facing relentless enemies, every moment is designed to keep you on your toes. 

The intricacy of the combat system encourages experimentation with different builds, making each playthrough unique. The world of Lordran is a masterpiece of design. The interconnected areas, hidden pathways, and clever shortcuts invite exploration and reward curiosity. The lore is rich and layered, unfolding through environmental storytelling and cryptic NPC interactions. Piecing together the history of the world is as satisfying as the combat itself, immersing players in a narrative that lingers long after the game is over.

The remaster includes upgraded online functionality, allowing for smoother multiplayer interactions. Cooperative play and competitive invasions are more accessible than ever, fostering a vibrant community that adds depth to the experience. Summoning friends for epic battles or engaging in thrilling PvP duels enhances the game’s replayability. The remastered sound design elevates the experience, with haunting melodies and impactful sound effects that enhance the immersion. From the echoing clang of weapons to the ominous ambiance of darkened areas, the audio design plays a crucial role in creating the oppressive atmosphere that Dark Souls is known for.

This game is not hard, and never was. It's one of the biggest collective lies in all of gaming. After you clear Sen's Fortress, the level design (mostly) stops being ass, enemies stop having way too much health and the game doesn't feel nearly as oppressive. Not a single boss in this game is more difficult than Gundyr from Dark Souls 3 (either version).

The main reason that this game is considered so challenging is because it is lacking so, so, SO many quality of life features that later Soulslikes would implement without a second thought. I cannot tell you how many times throughout my playthrough I had the thought "Man, if I was playing Elden Ring right now, I wouldn't have died there". And the argument that this is only the second real game of its kind can only go so far before it's clear that the design of this game is just inherently half-baked. If EVERY SINGLE game that comes after this one can get basic things about the genre correct, then I should be allowed to criticize their progenitor for not having them.

So why am I reviewing this positively if I have only negative things to say? Well, simply put, I still had a lot of fun. It felt cool to gradually see my character go from a guy who dies from a dust particle landing on him to a badass samurai pyromancer who can kill everything in a couple of strikes. The world feels well constructed and intricate, if a little barren compared to later Fromsoft titles (although I am really not a fan of how this game is basically a Metroidvania for its first half, but that's mostly because anyone who follows my reviews knows I just really hate Metroidvanias and the way they've commodified pointless backtracking in gaming). I have no idea why people say this game "peaks at Anor Londo". Most of my favorite levels--The Duke's Archives, Oolacile Township, The Painted World of Ariamis, etc.) can only be accessed after Ornstein and Smough, who by the way are still a really cool fight even if they've kind of been lionized to an unrealistic degree by the fanbase. In fact--and this is my real opinion, not a "le contrarian" one--I think my favorite level in this entire game is Lost Izalith. People give it so much shit for being "unfinished", but it doesn't feel that way while actually playing it, and it's such a cool environment with balanced enemy encounters (make fun of the copy-pasted Taurus Demons all you want, but they're appropriately scaled for the region) and a boss fight that is not anywhere as frustrating as hardcore soulslike players make it out to be. If you really start having a hissy fit over a boss with checkpoints, something almost NO soulslike bosses have, and that requires maybe three restarts minimum if you're bad at platforming or underleveled, why are you even playing this game (or a fan of this genre, for that matter)?

As I briefly mentioned, this game has a lot of the same problems as Demon's Souls in terms of boss quality, by which I mean the easy bosses are pitiful and the "hard" bosses are only hard if you've never ever played a game with this control scheme before or haven't leveled health. My favorite boss was probably Manus, because as neat as Artorias is he has some janky hitboxes and I feel like everything with Manus is fair and telegraphed while still providing a decently tense challenge.

Also as I mentioned, this game has an extremely punishing early-game that can feel genuinely unfun at times, but it is not the bugbear that everyone has always made it out to be. My father could probably beat this game with practice, and he plays games on story difficulty. (if you're somehow reading this, this is not a diss. I promise. I love you and respect your gaming decisions.) My hypothesis of how this game got its overinflated reputation for being difficult has always been that games journalists who couldn't get past Sen's Fortress or got stuck in Blighttown published stuff primarily dealing with the hardest parts of the game (to be clear, I am not being a chud "games journalists le bad" gamer here. They have a limited amount of time to review stuff and if they get stuck on something it's going to influence their perception of the game, and I don't hold it against them. They were just doing their jobs), which caused it to gain a reputation of being this SUPER DUPER ULTRA HARD MEGA BALL BUSTING GAME FOR REAL GAMERS ONLY when it's an averagely difficult fantasy RPG with a handful of challenging parts like any other. There have been games before and after Dark Souls that are much, much harder to play, let alone beat.

I guess what I'm trying to say with this winded review is that while I like Dark Souls and have huge respect for how it inspired several of my favorite games ever down the line, it isn't the untouchable masterpiece people say it is and beating it doesn't feel like a "badge of honor" in the same way beating other Soulslikes does to me. Thanks for listening to me ramble, you can advance my questline now.

Dang, this old masterpieces remastered version runs smooth on my old LCD Steamdeck. Just lovely! Read the entire review for more Deck-related informations.

Even with a TDP of 8W these 60FPS seem rock solid at the beginning of the game, going to edit my review if that'll change in later areas.

like in almost every game i use 1152x720 to trigger the decks internal FSR feature (most games require windowed mode to enable it, a minority fullscreen, check performance-overlay 4 if it is on or off) with sharpness set to 4 out of 5. 

That removes the slightly blurry visuals i get from the native 1280x800 resolution has and gives me a crisp and clean picture without any flickering in most games. It even makes more details pop out the textures that were lost in the blur.

Very cool idea, botched by poor execution. The game is not hard at all, I don't know what people talk about. It's just poorly designed in some very crucial places. 

Amazing:
- combat system - many enemies have a weak point that you can figure out eventually and exploit. This is very fun to explore. Some enemies are very dull though - titanite demon vs melee build is boring... You need to make 50 hits to kill it, can only make 1 hit between it's attack sequences so it takes ages.
- amazing world design
- no saves
- visuals

Good:
- no handholding
- difficulty level

All of this forces to have an experience as intended and brings enjoyable adrenaline-packed action experience. 

Bad:
- game design - for the game you are supposed to try different things there is too much grind. I can get to the boss with my eyes closed before I can figure out how to defeat them, making me try cheesy tactics in the most interesting part of the game. This means you spend 95% time doing same thing again just to get to the fun part, and don't enjoy the fun part because of fear to grind yet again. This is why we hate mobile games, this has the same vibe. I don't understand why not make checkpoints before boss fights. Souls are not that valuable to loose anyway, levels are super easy to grind.
- game design - for a game with this many narrow corridors, making melee attack hit against the wall was very silly choice. Basically weapons without thrusting attacks are very risky to use, so throw them away immediately. Same for narrow ledges - can't fight on them as attack animation like to do a little step to the side. Enemies are bugging out, takes minutes to lure them out, it's only fun first couple of times.
- bugs. For example rats... Poison is long lasting and is introduced in the game at the time where there is no antidote. It's super easy to avoid, however game often bugs on rats - sometimes they do double attacks (new attack animation starts in the mid of previous one), sometimes rats don't die - I just brought health bar to 0, and it's full again, no extra corpse. Basically, if game does not bug out - easy, if it does - guaranteed going back to bonfire, so we are back to point 1.
- camera. I play on PC and don't use lock on. Lock on is terrible - once enemy moves sometimes camera gets stuck against player and the wall, and I can't see anything. Without lock on I still need to babysit camera otherwise it turns randomly... 

Whilst I did enjoy the idea so much, I wish this was better made. If you really want to get into souls games, try another part in the franchise, maybe they improved with time. 

P.S. I still continued after writing the review, and I am ready to forgive many things for gargoyle boss fight. <3 However, I still believe this was unfinished game when released, and many omissions/mistakes were just marketed as intended "difficulty".

The first Dark Souls has always been a very special game for me. I was among the people who signed the petition to release a PC port. I spent hundreds of hours in Dark Souls: Prepare to Die Edition back in 2013, especially in PvP. And even after all the following games of From Software, I kept loving the first DS the most.

The DLC for Elden Ring was kind of a disappointment for me though. I still haven’t managed to complete it. I kept doing everything I could to avoid playing it. And eventually it brought me to Dark Souls Remastered. This was my first walkthough in a decade, which allowed me to look into the game from a different point of view. And the game is still great!

First Dark Souls has the most impressive world design in the series. It’s not a set of independent levels but an interconnected world, which unfolds while you progress through the game. I can’t even describe that joy I felt during my first playthrough, when I found that elevator leading to the Firelink Shrine from the Undead Church. And DS1 is full of such valuable shortcuts and passages to the previously visited locations.

The locations, their surroundings, enemies and items are very consistent with the game’s lore, which, for instance, DS2 lacks.

Later From Software games allow us to teleport to any bonfire from the very beginning. But DS1 gives the limited teleportation options only in the second half of the game. And now I understand this approach better due to all that interconnectedness of the world and shortcuts. This approach also makes the world exploration more consistent, since your learn all the locations by heart. Like I said, I hadn’t played DS1 for almost a decade, but I still remembered the geography of the world, and locations of the most valuable items and enemies. On the other hand, DS1 is full of backtracking, especially because some important NPCs are based in different and not always easily accessible places, so you have to run a lot.

DS1 combat system is less reliant on some magical attacks and special moves but rather on slow and tactical approach and studying the wide moveset of every weapon. You can find some of the best weapons, such as Zweihander or Claymore, in the first 20 minutes of playthrough. Also, the armor is, perhaps, the best in the series. Havel set, for instance, allows you to easily tank some of the bosses, which is unimaginable for the later games.

During my first playthrough, I had suffered from almost every single boss. I spent several hours on runbacks to Taurus demon. Kapra was burning my butt. Ornstein and Smough came to me in my nightmares. I remember shouting and running around my room when I first killed Artorias. With extensive experience with future From Software games, I can tell that DS1 is actually quite easy. Almost all the bosses are very slow, with predictable attacks and can be easily cheesed, if you know the tactics and their weaknesses. Even the Bed of Chaos can be easily cheesed. 

The Estus upgrade mechanics, as well as the Humanity parameter, are unique for the series.

The Estus is kinda dubious though. An experienced player can get the Rite of Kindling in the first 20 minutes of the game. In a casual playthrough though, you will get it only in the second part of the game. And kindling the bonfires requires spending the humanity, which is a limited consumable through the game, and farming it consistently becomes possible only at the later stages of the game. Also, you need to spend several humanities for a single bonfire, which means that you need to carefully choose which ones to invest in. And this, in turn, means that you will be running with 5-10 Estuses throughout most of the game. The Estus shards mechanic from the later game is much better, IMO. 

The Humanity itself is cool, since it implements kind of an additional high risk – high reward mechanics. Humanity increases your defense, resistances, item discovery and damage from the chaos weapons. You loose it with death but you have a chance to pick it up once, as well as your souls.

What if often criticized about DS1 is the second part of the game. While the trip to Anor Londo is very exciting and actually leaves an impression of a long road behind, the locations from the second part of the game are dull and poorly designed. In my opinion, there are good and bad locations through the whole game. I love the Undead Parish, Anor Londo and Duke’s Archieves as much as I hate the Depths, Blighttown, Tombs the Giants and Izalith.

Another aspect of the first Dark Souls is that it is not the most technologically advanced game from PS3 and Xbox 360. And even the Remastered version looks like an old and sometimes ugly game. It does not scare me, but it might scare new players, who came from Elden Ring.

An Unforgettable Journey:
I recently completed Dark Souls Remastered, and I can confidently say that it's one of the most captivating and rewarding gaming experiences I’ve ever had. Yes, this game is notoriously hard and brutal, but that challenge is exactly what makes it so addictive. Every encounter feels like a test of skill, patience, and perseverance, and the feeling of finally overcoming a tough boss is unlike anything else.But Dark Souls isn’t just about difficulty—it’s a masterclass in storytelling. The game’s lore is deep, intricate, and beautifully woven into the world. Rather than spoon-feeding the plot, it encourages players to piece together the story themselves, which made it resonate with me on a much deeper level. The atmosphere is dark, mysterious, and immersive, pulling me further into its world with every step.

The NPCs, too, are wonderfully crafted. Among them, Solaire of Astora, aka “Sunbro” .His unwavering optimism and desire to “praise the sun” provided a perfect contrast to the game's often bleak tone. He’s a character that stays with you long after you put down the controller.
If you’re someone who enjoys a challenge and appreciates a richly developed world, Dark Souls Remastered is a must-play. It’s more than just a game; it’s an experience that stays with you long after the final boss is defeated.

I was originally nervous to play Dark Souls because I had already experienced everything Form Software learned throughout the Souls series, so I might see it as worse than the rest. Well I was half right, Dark Souls does some things worse than the games that came after, but it also does things no other game in the series ever tries again. Despite its flaws as a “first” of many, it is still truly an awesome game that introduced so much to the world. I respect it like I would Ocarina of Time, except it’s actually fun to play. I’d like to talk about all of the little things that make this game great and a piece of work.

This game’s combat is more stilted than it is in the rest of the series. Bosses may look cool but they fight so simply to the point that their designs or movements don’t matter, you just do the same thing every time. Having played the rest of the games, they’re also pretty easy. The main character’s movement isn’t the best but it gets the job done. I remember it was very frustrating when I killed an enemy and their body still blocked me, leading to me getting killed by others surrounding me. This was a temporary issue though. Everyone knows the last third of the game feels rushed. The demon area is practically empty, the giant tree boss is probably the worst boss I’ve fought in the Souls series, the crystal area is cool, but also pretty empty, its boss is not a great time, and the depths of the catacombs are hardly worth mentioning. Gwyn is also a total pushover once you reach him. If it weren’t for this game’s DLC, things would have ended on a sour note, but it didn’t. This leads to what I adore about this game. 

The first thing I found unique about DS1 was its paintbrush art style and sound design. In the right places, like Firelink Shrine, everything looks and sounds soothing. When looking at the distance in large areas like Anor Londo and the Great Hollow, there’s a blurriness that I prefer over it being a sharp image. There was a large lack of ambient music which made me appreciate the sounds surrounding me. The wind blowing on rooftops, the noises of the forest, the emptiness of the catacombs, and the constant clinking of my armor immersed me more than any music could. The voice acting in this game (besides the player character since he sounds like he’s having an orgasm whenever he gets hit) is unlike any other game I have played. I honestly can’t describe how they all sound but it just feels right and calming in a way. The massively titted woman was an excellent reward for beating Ornstein and Smough. Because of DS3, I was dead set on completing Seigmeyer’s quest. He was such a jolly guy. I reached the point where he was looking down at a bunch of monsters and he needed my help to kill them. I poison-arrowed four of them and left the last one to him. He dropped down, we attacked at the same time, and Havel armored dumbass killed him with my giant strength build sword. This devasted me far more than the intended ending for his questline could. I found the way you start and kindle your flame quite satisfying what with how the fire crackled more as it grew bigger. I grew to appreciate how interconnected this world was. It was daunting at first but it became easy to know exactly how to get anywhere. Different areas blended together as if they were all one area. It’s honestly impressive that this was their first attempt at making an interconnected world and it is still one of the best I have ever seen. Despite my nagging about how inconsequential most of the bosses felt, there are some real highlights. My favorite in the base game was the Four Kings. This wasn’t because of how they fought or looked, but because the battleground was pitch black so it was difficult to determine how far away you are from them. Me running at them and swinging too soon felt like I was in a dream where I couldn’t catch up to someone. The Painted Lady freaked me out when she disappeared and beat me up with her scythe and Sif, the giant sword-wilding wolf, was also exciting and sad to play against. I like that he gets a different cutscene if you do the DLC before fighting him. Speaking of the DLC, it hits like a truck. I was taken aback by how intimidating and heart-pumping Artorias was to fight. It was a huge improvement over the base game and is easily the most memorable in DS1. He’s also a Berserk reference with his vertical flip swing. The area leading up to Manus genuinely creeped me out when the humanity ghosts appeared, the illusory ledge disappeared, and when I found a small Sif guarded by those ghosts. Manus was one of the only bosses where I had to make a second attempt against him because I was so intimidated by him. All of the cutscenes in the DLC were killer but watching the blind giant smithy snipe the dragon out of the sky made my jaw drop. At the end of all this, I had such a great time in the DLC but I was also underwhelmed by how short it was. It was finally time to take on Gwyn. Entering his area and seeing the beautiful desolation of the coliseum was an excellent lead-up to him. I still wish he weren’t so easy but his music popped off. As the credits of this game rolled, I was deeply satisfied with this game despite my frustrations, which perfectly sums up every great souls-like game out there, except this one started it all. What a behemoth of a game. Miyazaki, you crazy fuck, you did it again.

Dark Souls is basically the line of quality for this type of game, but by no means is it perfect. I do personally feel as though newer games, both from From Soft and other devs have largely worked to fix almost every main issue.

Dark Souls introduced the world to Demon's Souls, a Playstation 3 exclusive that managed to win several accolades and generate a very good user impression, but was bogged down by being on the PS3, a system that was failing at the time to keep up with the faster selling Xbox 360. Demon's Souls has only a few elements not seen in Dark.

Enter Lordran, a dying kingdom beyond the reality. You are an Undead, a human who walks the land, forever unable to die. Most are like this, and many have been corralled into the Asylum, where you start to await the end of the world, but few have kept their sanity, or at least shreds of it, and roam the land in search of a way to complete the Undead's Goal, to ring two bells of Awakening and learn the final part of their task. To do this, you'll create a character, choose a class and starting item and then be unleashed with little guidance beyond the few cryptic NPCs you do find.

The world is still the highlight of this game, discovering secret passages and opening gates makes traversing this highly unforgiving land interesting and rewarding as it loops in on itself and interconnects. The lore is sparse enough to not require your care, but deep enough to fill a novel or two, should you delve into it.

pros of Dark Souls generally:
-brilliant game--despite my own complaints and its obtrusive difficulty, or perhaps because of them, its one of the most rewarding games ever made. Beating a boss you have been struggling against and surmounting impossible odds will always be amongst the best feelings in gaming.
-storyline intentionally invokes themes of oppression, depression, and impossibility; not only is it rewarding to be able to dispatch bosses because of the VERY hard nature of this game, but the scant NPCs and cutscenes support you as fulfilling an impossible task. Those with depression or anxiety tend to connect to this game intensely.

pros of the PC version:
-60 fps MASSIVELY improves the playability and feel of the game. having come from console versions (that i could never beat), i can flatly state that the game is better, slightly easier, and more fun for it.
-rebindable controls are always a plus, and the KB/M controls mostly match newer From Software games. also works with extra mouse inputs.
-game looks good, and will run at 60 fps on 4k res with just about any mid tier system. also takes less than 10 GBs of space.


now we move on to the stuff some newer games have fixed:
-this is the slowest Souls/Borne, save the original Demons Souls. Every newer game feels more responsive without sacrificing the intentionality.
-newer games aren't easier to play, but easier to KEEP playing--other games have more optional bosses and a few choice QoL improvements to reduce frustration. When you hit a boss you dont think you can beat, there's almost nowhere to go and nothing to do aside from grind souls and buy better gear or level up.

I do not recommend without a sale, 40 dollars for a 6 year old remaster of a 15 year old game with basically dead multiplayer feels wrong. I also don't really recommend it for curiosity, if you liked Elden Ring, maybe try Sekiro or Dark Souls 3 instead, as this one is significantly clunkier.

Can't call yourself a true Soulsborne fan without truly experiencing this game. Enjoyed every second of my playtime exploring the world, learning about the lores and secrets, fighting the bosses, developing new builds, and many countless other crazy things. If you're a swordplay enjoyer just like me this game is a MUST.

The controls aren't great either, the movement is slow, and dodge rolling is clunky compared to newer Souls games. It’s frustrating to walk around and constantly get stuck on small ledges in the terrain. While the tutorial dungeon is well designed, the game quickly becomes unbalanced afterward: even the weakest skeleton enemies have about ten times more health than they should, making them tedious to defeat. You can't simply run past them either, as they'll chase you through the entire first area, which is more irritating than challenging.

Overall, the game feels outdated, and I can’t recommend it in 2024.

Instead, I suggest getting Elden Ring, which is an excellent game, or trying Dark Souls III.

You can beat Dark Souls. yes, you. you reading this, looking through the comments with an angry attitude trying to find people getting toxic about casual players, you can beat this game. anyone can. Dark Souls is filled to the brim with assists and aid and relief in places you'd never expect to find it. 

Dark Souls is like no other game I've ever played. at once profoundly beautiful and hideous, profoundly rewarding and frustrating, elating and depressing, light, and dark. without the struggle of bullshit deaths to the capra demon, the triumph of beating it wouldn't be the same. without the misery of crawling through Blighttown, the glorious sky of Anor Londo wouldn't be as jaw dropping. the game will be rough to play. it absolutely will. but you can beat it, and when you're standing in front of the door to the final boss, thinking back on each roadblock you found insurmountable, that feeling will stay with you for your entire life. 

also, practical advice for people who genuinely want to give the game a fair shot, pick Pyromancer, go for a strength build, and grab the Zwihander from behind firelink shrine, just sprint past the skeletons. that's a weapon you can beat the entire game with, (and i have, twice) so you can't go wrong with upgrading it, and should do that as often as possible.

I get what all the fuss is about, the game gets so hard to put down. Every zone, every item and npc just pulls you further into the mysterious land of Lordran. The games inter-connected zones are just amazing, there is usually multiple ways to get to an area, some more secretive then others. I found the second half just as enjoyable as the first, when looking at the story all the zones just really make sense and fit the narrative. True, they are not all on the Anor Londo scale of vistas, but climbing down into the swamp from the rafters of Blightown and to the darkness of the Catacombs, they were all great. But watch out for those Bone Wheels, they can truly ruin your day quick. All the bosses were enjoyable in their own ways and none weren't overly that difficult. Even Manus was bested around 40 attempts. Tons of weapons, spells and builds to choose from to fit many styles. It's fun, challenging and really intriguing. Really just an awesome game all around.

This game, something about it has perpetually wedged itself in my brain since first playing it in 2011. Maybe it has something to do with it being the modern day Zelda game that I have always wanted, but it might be something deeper. My first games were the likes of Myst and Riven where you are a random person dropped in a strange world and the only thing you can do is "fix" it. Dark Souls embodies this concept just with an extra layer of engaging combat. 

In some ways FromSoftware has gone on to do better but always with an asterisk. Dark Souls 2 had better combat and improved frame rates, but lacked the same engaging boos fights and story. Dark Souls 3 has some of the best bosses of the series, but the level design is nowhere near as compelling. Elden Ring gets back to the root of the "feeling" of playing the first Dark Souls, but all becomes a bland slog through an open world. This all excluding Bloodborne which is the best game they've made.

Incredible, iconic and irritating are words I would use to describe Dark Souls.

In case your Intimidated by everyone saying the game is super hard, only for hardcore gamers and masochists or anything else of that sort: thats just not really the case. Dark Souls can be enjoyed and played by everyone and is pretty accesible even to casual gamers. The core game might be pretty challenging but theres lots of ways to make the game easier: Summoning NPCs to help you out, using walkthroughs, cheese strategys, grinding levels early on. All these are strategys that can make your expierience much, much smoother. aside from that, i would give the game like a 9,5 out of 10: The gameplay is not as fast paced, adrenaline loaded and smooth as in most other Soulsborne games but stays fun and exiting, the lore, story and athmosphere of this game are amazing. What loses the game the 10/10 is just jankyness, bugs and some kinda bad game design at some points (especially around the second half of the game).
I really really recommend this game even if youre a more casual gamer, definetly one of my favorite games.

Dark Souls is a game that forever changed the way we view action RPGs. From the very first moments it attracts with its dark, enigmatic atmosphere that arouses fascination and anxiety. It's a game that doesn't lead the player by the hand - on the contrary, it throws him into a mysterious, harsh world where every encounter can be deadly and every decision is crucial.

The most impressive element of Dark Souls is its well-thought-out level design. The world of Lordran is an intricately connected network of locations that we discover step by step, full of hidden shortcuts, secrets and carefully designed challenges. This world has a life of its own - from deserted castles, through dark catacombs, to hellish depths, each element seems to have its own story. A perfectly balanced balance of difficulties and rewards makes each completion of a difficult part of the game a feeling of pure satisfaction.

FIrst of all i must say, it's a hard game. So if you enjoy hard games it's for you. If you enjoy plug and play games with minimum difficulty this is probably not for you. But it may actually be! 

Before i go on a rant, yes it is single player and it has online functions like CO-OP and PVP. Now the co-op is not what you might expect. You need to become human and place a mark so that another player interact with it and then he will come to your world on specific areas so that you both can play together. There is a PVP zone after the boss artorias.

You see, Dark souls 1/ remastered is a game that gives the player the freedom to choose where to go next with almost zero help. There is no Map and you will feel a bit lost at the start. (THE ENTIRE MAP IS ONE BIG MAZE).
You will try one area and then another one and you will see, maybe i am not ready to take on that path so i must choose another one. Luckly for you the first half of the game has a very linear path to follow.

You will rage quit, you will want to say "this is totally not fair", you will be frustrated. All this things are there because you don't understand the game really. Once you understand the game, how it works, how the animations work, how everything is connected and you know all the places and where to go, then this is a easy game. So with hard work the game will become easy. 

Amazing lore, but the lore is not given with cutscenes. Every item you will pick will have a story behind it. So always read the item description and learn more about the age of fire.

GAIN THE COURAGE AND BUY THE GAME AND FINISH IT LIKE THE BOSS YOU ARE! If i can finish the game so can you!

I highly recommend. Praise the sun.

After completing Dark Souls: Remastered, I have mixed feelings about my experience. While it has its standout moments, I found it less engaging compared to other titles in the series. The game can be quite confusing, often leaving players to navigate without clear guidance. I frequently relied on guides to find my way, which detracted from the sense of exploration I enjoy in other Souls games.

That said, the boss fights in Dark Souls are truly remarkable. Each encounter feels unique and challenging, pushing players to develop strategies and master timing. My Faith build, paired with the Mace, provided a rewarding combat experience, allowing me to deal solid damage while using supportive miracles. The satisfaction of triumphing over a tough boss remains a highlight of the game.

The world design is iconic, with interconnected areas that reward exploration—when you can find your way. The atmosphere is rich and haunting, immersing you in a dark fantasy that feels both oppressive and intriguing.

Overall, while Dark Souls: Remastered has its brilliant moments, particularly in combat and boss design, the lack of clear navigation and its overall confusion left me feeling frustrated at times. It’s worth playing for fans of the series, but it didn't resonate with me as strongly as other entries.

Let me tell u, Drak Soles Remastard aint juts a game; it's like a live-action documentary of my endless war against bed bugz. U think Gwynn, Lord of Cinders, is tuf? Try battlin' a horde of tiny blood-suckin' bastards every nite that turn ur bed into the battlefield of absolute dispare. The game sez "Prepere to Die," but it realy means "Prepere to Scratch Until U Bleed," because this game, like bed bugs, will smash ur soul into a million lil itchy bits of regret and torment.

From the momment u hit start, it's like gettin’ in the rusty armer of a middle evil bug man, armed with nuthin but a brkn sword and a dream of vengence. Fog gates? More like it’s the layers of ur peese of mind gettin shredded, each new area filled with enemys more relentless than my aunt betsy on meth. U think Blighttwn is bad? Try layin back down at 3 AM with skin crawlin’ from the thot of those tiny legged demons skitterin' thru ur pillows like they're doin' the Macarena. Tomato soup.

And the bonfires? Ha! They're as useful as that cheap bed bug spray the dollar store sells—it smells like victory, but ur just foolin’ urself. U spray, u pray, u burn all ur clothes in a fire that smells like ur shattered dreams, but every morning ur back to square one, bitten and pissed off like Ornstein and Smough jus tag-teamed ur sanity. As a girl dealin with this nitemare, it feels like there’s no escape—like even my hair’s a battlefield of itchin’ terror.

Boss fights? Plz, fighting Artorias is just like tryna catch that one sneaky ass bed bug who’s smarter than u, dodgin' ur hits like he’s Neo from the Matrix, but it's not the Matrix, it’s ur bedroom and ur losing. The Capra Demonn? That’s like my landlord slammin' the door in my face while two mangy dogs (bed bugs) bite at my heels, and somehow the moon is involved because it totally makes sense.

And let’s talk bout the Estus Flask. In Drak Soles, healing is like finding a clean shirt that hasn’t been tainted by the invasion of tiny invincible vampires. One sip and u think ur safe, but nope, those bed bugs, like the game’s enemies, keep on respawning and by the way why does everything smell like bananas in this world? You patch one hole, one bite, one infestation, and suddenly there’s a chicken doing the cha-cha in ur closet.

In the end, Drak Soles Remastard isn’t just a game; it’s a frickin' life philosophy, a manifesto of madness, an endless cycle of death, resurrection, and me just tryna sleep in peace for ONCE. It’s about refusing to give up, about getting back up no matter how many bites, no matter how many times u die, because the struggle is ETERNAL. And honestly, if I could just parry bed bugs like I do in the game, life would be almost manageable.

So here's my review: 5/5. Drak Soles Remastard is the perfect simulashun of a bed bug apocalypse—a punishing, itch-inducing mess-terpiece that makes u want more, even when u kno it’s terrible for ur sanity. Now where the hell did I put my sword and my sanity?

Experience – First Time

Setting/World – 9/10
Story – 8.5/10
Music – 9.5/10
Voice Acting – 9/10
Game play – 9/10

Overall Review – 9/10

Plot
You are an ‘undead’, traversing the dilapidated world of Lordran, which is long past it’s prime. After learning of your fate as the ‘chosen undead’, you must destroy the lords of the world, who have all gone insane and past their usefulness. 

Review

World
The World of Lordran is what makes the game so awesome! When the opening cutscene ends, and the player is shown, he/she is seen rotting away in Undead Asylum, awaiting their fate. You start your journey from there. After defeating a few bosses, you are transported to Lordran, by what, I will not spoil. After reaching Firelink Shrine in Lordran, you are free to go where ever you want, you can go up to Undead Parish, or down to Blighttown, you can fight ghosts or fight skeletons, the decision is up to you, which is an amazing design choice for exploring the world. 

There are only a few places in the game which will seem unfair, because it requires certain items which you can only get later in the game, or by chance.

Game play
After the world, the most impressive thing about the game was its gameplay. The shear number of options you have at your disposal is frankly mind blowing! You can go for str. build, or magic build, you can make a weapon divine or make it raw, you can have aux effect on your weapon, you can ascend you weapon to follow a path. The choices frankly overwhelm you when you are first starting out, but once you get familiar with it, it becomes a rewarding experience. 

The same thing is true for your player progression, you are given choices on how to scale your player, which stats to scale. 
The combat mechanics, although simple to understand like:  light attack, strong attack, parry, backstab, roll etc, never feels simple or easy to execute, because the world in which you have to use this is unforgiving, one wrong move, and you will be squashed like a mosquito by bosses 10 feet higher than you.

There are a lot more, but you get the idea.

Story
Dark Souls has an interesting way of telling you the story, which is, by not telling it. The opening cutscene gives you background of the World of Lordran. After that, it is entirely up to you to discover, evaluate: what is your purpose in this world; what are you supposed to do in this world. The best way to understand the world is by interacting with npcs. I can’t write more, or it will go in spoiler territory. 

Music
Amazing Music!! The moment you start your game from Firelink Shrine, you are blessed with amazing music. The game does not have any ambiance music, which will seem strange at first, but once you realize that music is only used for boss fights, and some bonfires, you will appreciate it.

Voice Acting
The protagonist does not utter a word, nor does the bosses in the entire game. You only hear voices of npcs, but what an amazing job their respectable voice actor did.

Overall Review
I loved the game!! I had only heard of dark souls before, watched a few videos, laughed at a few memes, but never actually played the game, because I had heard about its difficulty and nothing more. But after completing it, I can safely say, the game is much more than being difficult. It has depth, story, gameplay, music, all the things that makes a game memorable, and that is where I will end my review. I will remember Dark Souls, not for being difficult, which it is, but for being an amazing game.

P.S
Spoilers!! The player, after the end boss battle, will be given an option to prolong the age of fire, or start the age of darkness.

[h1] I Liked Dark Souls 2 More [/h1] 
[u]8/10[/u]
Yes, you didn't read that wrong, I did actually like Dark Souls 2 more then Dark Souls 1. Dark Souls 2 was my first ever 'Souls-Like' and even though its the most hated game in the genre, Its still my favorite one from the ones I've played. Call me crazy, call me masochist, but I don't care. Dark Souls 2 will always have a special place in my heart, despite all of its issues. I won't ever forget the first time I slayed a boss, after trying for hours, I won't ever forget the first time beating it. It felt like I truly achieved something. With Dark Souls 1 (Or Remastered, whatever) I was trying to replicate that feeling but it just didn't work for me personally. The entire game was too easy, except an area here and there or a boss or two. A lot of Quality of Life improvments were missing here which were present in Dark Souls 2 which I guess is to be expected since Dark Souls 2 is obviously a sequel. For example I wasn't a fan of not being able to fast travel between bonfires until you find a certain item, and even then you can't fast travel between all bonfires, only 'major' ones. In other words, there is a lot of running around in order to go from one point of the map to another. To be fair, there are a lot of short cuts that you can unlock and then use, but even then, much easier to just fast travel to a bonfire I've already been too. You can only equip 2 rings instead of 4, which felt strange to be honest. I love using a lot of rings in 'Souls-Like' games. There are more example I can think of but you get the point. Overall, not a bad game by any means, I enjoyed most of it and would easily recommened it for people who like 'Souls-Like' games but haven't played Dark Souls 1. It just didn't replicate that feeling which Dark Souls 2 gave me years ago, which is perhaps what I was looking for.

It's a shame the latest stuff in their portfolio has drifted away from the original design philosophy of this and Demon's Souls, but everyone ends up selling out, justifying it, and then gaslighting the fan-base about it anyway these days.

There are lots of things to not like about Dark Souls. It is opaque, plodding, and will punish you relentlessly for making the same mistakes again and again. All those things give you a greater sense of achievement when you finally learn what this game is, and isn't, and learn to work that system to your enjoyment.
 The game is also very good at making sure you do not become complacent. New focuses and challenges will make you adapt quickly on your feet, or have to start from a minor progress loss where you have more time to think and determine your method of approach.
 Like most games from Japan, the accessibility factors are quite lacking. And that is incredibly unfortunate. I have a friend who is legally blind who can not play this game because of it's visual style and language.
 No game is for everyone. Dark Souls will do it's best to let you know early on that it isn't for you. But for those of us it is for, there's nothing else like it. Tread carefully, pay attention, and lean on the community.

Explore incredible places far from the Mushroom Kingdom as you join DARK SOULS and his new ally Cappy on a massive, globe-trotting 3D adventure. Use amazing new abilities—like the power to capture and control objects, animals, and enemies—to collect Power Moons so you can power up the Odyssey airship and save Princess Peach from Bowser’s wedding plans!

Thanks to heroic, hat-shaped Cappy, DARK SOULS’s got new moves that’ll make you rethink his traditional run-and-jump gameplay—like cap jump, cap throw, and capture. Use captured cohorts such as enemies, objects, and animals to progress through the game and uncover loads of hidden collectibles. And if you feel like playing with a friend, just pass them a Joy-Con™ controller! Player 1 controls DARK SOULS while Player 2 controls Cappy. This sandbox-style 3D Mario adventure—the first since 1996’s beloved DARK SOULS II™ and 2002’s Nintendo GameCube™ classic DARK SOULS III™—is packed with secrets and surprises, plus exciting new kingdoms to explore.

This is my favorite series of all time. DS1 is the slowest and most methodical of the three, which I personally enjoy. Most bosses have mechanics that are simple to learn, with a few powerhouses peppered in. The different areas are incredibly unique, from a forest on the edge of a dark valley, to a sunken city, to an undead town, to the city of the gods, to the essence of darkness itself. 

The deeper lore is not entirely obvious at first, but by reading item descriptions and paying attention to the environment, a more connected story begins to form right before your eyes. 

The builds are also incredibly varied. There are fast weapons, huge weapons,  ranged weapons, different movesets. There is also magic: sorceries, miracles, and pyromancy. 

As you grow stronger throughout the game you prepare to take on powerful bosses to fulfill your goal, along the way you’ll meet both friend and foe, have fun and prepare to die

It's easy to see why this game changed the face of the industry, why there are so many games now emulating the format. Truly a masterwork. Every step is so intentional, revealing striking vistas as you progress through each area. The world feels cohesive and immersive, fantastical and yet familiar in its austere brutality. The progression of the game feels organic, imbuing the player with a sense of belonging within the narrative, even as they are forced to make polarizing choices time after time. Can't say enough about this game. Can't wait to play more from FromSoft.

The first time I played Dark Souls I had just dumped something like my 600th hour into Elden Ring and I was finally ready to take on the Souls series. I absolutely hated this game. The clunky movement, the ganks, the limited rolling when locked on, the simplistic bosses, and the runbacks and backtracking all contributed to the fact that the game just didn't click for me and I dropped the game soon after beating the Taurus demon.

However, after beating Shadow of the Erdtree a couple of times I decided to give Dark Souls another shot on a new character, and after a small period of adjustment (as you'd expect, it plays much differently to Elden Ring) I was hooked. This time I wasn't spending my playtime being frustrated by dated game design or jank, but instead I found myself taking things slowly, observing and immersing myself in the world of Lordran, and overall playing the game a bit more tactically. This is, in my opinion, how Dark Souls wants you to play it. All the same core mechanics of a Soulslike are here -- the build variety, the dodge rolls, the stamina bar, the cryptic lore & NPC questlines, etc. -- yet there is a beautiful simplicity to Dark Souls. The game is honestly pretty relaxing coming off of Elden Ring and you're expected to be more careful in your approach rather than learn complex strings of inputs to dodge and punish equally complex boss combos and unleash powerful weapon arts of your own like in the later games.

I personally have fallen in love with Dark Souls and it's an easy recommendation if you can overlook some of its flaws. The game isn't perfect (I'm not sure you need me to tell you that levels like the Tomb of the Giants and Lost Izalith can fuck right off) and if you've already spent a lot of time with other Souls games it might even feel a bit easy, but at its heart the game still perfectly exemplifies all the best qualities of the Souls series and I could see myself returning to it as a sort of 'comfort game'. Also, speaking to the remastered edition itself, I personally didn't have any issues playing through this version though I'm not savvy to any changes which may or may not have been made compared to the original release or PTDE. Overall, Dark Souls is a solid game and a good entry point into the series for anyone who might want a change of pace coming off of Elden Ring or who has no previous experience with any Soulslikes, though if you fall into the latter category you may find this game more difficult than I made it out to be.

A timeless classic RPG that has the most wonderful world design and NPCs I've ever experienced in gaming. Most of the areas are super interesting and unique and there is just so much to explore and figure out as you go along your adventure. The DLC is fantastic as well and features some of the more ambitious and fun bosses. There are a select few unscrupulous sections such as Capra demon, Blighttown and Bed of Chaos that will make you ponder your life choices on your long runs back but overall the game is very fair and rewarding. While the bosses generally might not be the best the series has to offer (I think due to the "slower" combat compared to the other entries) the good ones are so iconic and memorable that they shine so much brighter than the stinkers. All in all, Dark Souls 1 has high highs and low lows and it really ties into the theme that there can't be light without darkness. It is a journey everyone should embark on at least once!

Some aspects of this genre-defining game are obnoxious, frustrating, and totally not fun.
Still, it you have time, strong will, and perseverance, you "might" enjoy the game and what it offers.

[+]
1) Good performance
Stable framerate (though, only 60 FPS), with no freezes or stutters.
2) Unique boss mechanics
3) Cool-looking weapons and armor

[-]
1) Atrocious controls
Keyboard & Mouse controls are so bad, this alone ruins the gameplay.
2) Long runs to bosses
Some bonfires are so far away to bosses, that you spend 10 times more running back to a boss, than actually fighting a boss. Something like this: 1-2 minute run, (half or less health, 2-3 flasks left), 10 second fight, repeat.
This alone ruins the fun and makes rage quit the game.
3) Bad balance
Skill/boss/weapon balancing is badly designed.
4) Bad and forgetful music
5) Atrocious UI design
UI is designed by a madman for a madmen.
Plus, you can accidentally strike/kill NPCs while talking with them or browsing goods...
Very "thoughtful" design.
6) Low framerate
Only 60 FPS. At least it's stable.
7) Vague story
Only if you collect all bits and pieces, the story will be somewhat clear, otherwise it's so vague, you don't understand what is going on.

Conclusion: 5/10
