Two playthroughs down, what can be said about Dark Souls? It's so much more than just a difficult dark fantasy game that the series got so popular. It's almost like a way of life. Upon writing this review I have 28 hours logged in the past two weeks because it's just that damn good. The game will kick you 6 ways to Sunday and you will get angry and frustrated and confused and you will want to give up. But you can't. This game is entirely different to any other title you could play. Something just kept me coming back to this game every time, I was willingly throwing myself at a brick wall in hopes that this time I'd put a small crack in it. Nothing kept me going except determination, to conquer this game and see what came next. And when I did it felt so incredibly rewarding. I bought this game back in 2022 mainly just because I wanted to play Bloodborne and decided to start at the beginning, played on and off, made it the Depths in 2023, then just stopped. I only came back because I noticed it had been a whole year since I last played and decided to not let that 67 dollars go to waste, and I'm so glad I did. I realise I haven't really said anything specific about why I think Dark Souls is great, but it's something you just need to experience. Try it, get angry, overcome that anger, nothing can beat that feeling. Be safe, friend. Don't you dare go Hollow.

Punishing but rewarding, frustrating but satisfying.

This game punishes over confidence but rewards caution, skill, and tenacity. The under lying mechanics are often found on the wiki instead of in-game so some studying is advised but not necessary. There are many play styles accommodated such as archer, mage, warrior, thief, and pyromancer(FFIIRREE!!!!). Weapons range from daggers, wands & staves to halberds & spears, can be 2-handed, dual wielded, or combined with a shield. Enemies are sufficiently varied in their attacks and visual designs, bosses are hard but beatable & memorable. Story is light with few cutscenes or npcs and can be mostly ignored but each npc & their quest are well done.

After playing Elden Ring, I wanted to try out the Souls series, starting with the first. I had heard about it's interconnected level design, it's atmospheric setting, and it's weighty combat. I was ready to see how awesome this classic is. But 34 hours later, and all I feel is disappointed.

I think I should mention the good before I say why I gave a dislike. The biggest three things are the interconnected levels, the atmosphere, and the weighty combat. I have to give credit where credit is due, the way the map fits together is very smart. There was a lot of moments where I went "wait, that's connected?" and the mental map of Lordran became clearer and larger. The atmosphere was also really good. It felt cozy, almost like a fairy tale. And the combat felt a lot more focused than other titles. Unfortunately, that's where my praise ends.

As cozy as the game feels, it also feels cheeky. There are so many things in this game that feel like they're there because f**k you, that's why. There are countless minor and major annoyances in every area and every aspect that eventually you really start to feel it after a while. Obtuse stats, awful enemy placement, gankfests from even the weakest enemies, bizarre geometry interactions, ridiculous runbacks and travel time, you name it. Everything felt very unrefined and very unfinished. 

Despite all of this, I gave it a fair shot. I beat Ornstein and Smough and acquired the Lordvessel. Google says that's about halfway through the game, which I think is enough to make up my mind. But the game feels lacking in so many areas. Flawed masterpiece is the best way to describe this game. Because I can see the greatness, but it's hidden behind so many flaws that ultimately I have to say I disliked it more than I liked it.

[h1] Dark Souls, the best game I never played [/h1]

That is, until now of course.

2011 was quite a year for gaming looking back. A quick google search and seeing the amount of iconic games that came out that year, and compare it to now, my god we had it good back then!

Anyway, to get back to the point I'm trying to make, Dark Souls came out that year and it was a revolutionary game. Yet the Souls games are something I never dared go near. I'm not sure exactly why, probably mainly a fear of being bad at them, the seemingly overly difficult game play just wasn't my thing back then, and I was probably too stuck into Skyrim.

I finally bit the bullet and decided to get into the Souls games as my brother was getting into Elden Ring, which I also bought but haven't touched yet. I wanted to start from the beginning (sadly Demon's Souls isn't on Steam.. yet), so I delved into Dark Souls: Remastered.

Well I am so glad did play it. From the get go the world of Dark Souls captivated me, a world truly Dark indeed, for a game people say doesn't have much story, it absolutely does! The devil is in the details I guess.

And yes, the game is tough. The game is challenging. The game can be difficult. But, the game teaches you to "git gud", it's a game of trial and error, dying is integral to the experience. It's so integral to the story as well. The world is dying and everything is relying on you not to give up, but to do better and succeed. And when you do succeed, it feels great. This is one of the few games I've really felt such a sense of pride and accomplishment (heh). I actually felt like I grew as a player lol.

One thing that amazed me was the world design. The interconnected-ness and when you first experience is top notch. I was blown away to take that elevator and end up back where I did. And the game has lots of little branches that bring you back to familiar spots.

That being said, I did have my fair share of frustrations at times. Certain areas, enemies or bosses [spoiler] (F*ck you Capra Demon) [/spoiler] will make you want to rage, and I'll admit that there were certain parts where I had to look up a video on just how I could possibly get past it. But the Souls-borne community is perhaps one of the best I have come across. And the meme culture around it all is absolutely brilliant. I love how the game has a lore explanation for the multiplayer as well.

A lot of people have claimed that Dark Souls has a masterpiece first half, and a meh second half. I wouldn't go quite as far to call the second half bad, however, there are one or two areas [spoiler] (F*ck you Lost Izalith) [/spoiler] at the end where you can feel they had to wrap up development and therefore doesn't have quite the polish as others.

The DLC portion of the game was quite the jump up in difficulty, however this is not a bad thing. In fact the increase in challenge and setting of this DLC was probably my favorite overall.

Lastly, one of my favorite aspects of Dark Souls were the NPCs. I completely get why people love the characters that are present, whether it's Sun bro or the bumbling and loveable onion knight, the NPCs add so much to the experience even though they aren't exactly complex. I made sure that I completed each NPC's quest, and each of their stories really pictured just how bleak and how important it is to keep going.

[h2][i] Too f*cking long, I ain't reading all that [/i][/h2]

In essence, Dark Souls is a true genre-defining game with excellent world building, level design, amazing game play, a surprisingly rich story for those who want it, and most of all a rewarding experience.

I was so happy to experience, learn and master the game, I even set out to 100% all achievements which took me 2.5 playthroughs. It was well worth it.

2024 Review from a person who has not played any of the actual Dark Souls games, but has completed all of Elden Ring and Sekiro.  I finished this one after 37 hours, taking my time.

The graphics are a bit dated and the mechanics are a little clunky, but the game holds up.  The way the map is structured is amazing.  All of the levels loop around and into each other, so even though you don't get fast travel until fairly deep in the game it does not drag.  I did have to look up a map though from time to time as there is not one in the game and I didn't memorize all of that.  From a pure "tracing back to the roots of what this type of game is" perspective this one is worth playing.  I did play it on the steam deck for a decent portion of the time.

As for difficulty, I was surprised to discover that it was sort of easy.  I have completed Elden Ring + DLC and Sekrio so it may just be that I  have "got gud".  The combat is slower paced than those games but more deliberate.  If you press to swing your sword twice you better have meant it, because it is swinging twice.  The difficulty in this game was not really in the bosses in my opinion, but in the runbacks and the level parkour.  More of that later.

One of the things that does not get talked about much is the game's sense of humor.  Its the baked in little things, like only Rats have humanity.  For example, One of the first bosses in the game is fought on top of a rather narrow wall.  While fighting him, I turned him so that his back was to the edge.  When he jumped away from me, he jumped off the wall to his death; Victory Achieved.  Hilarious.  Other times the game pranks you, saying "You thought one gargoyle was the boss?  How about 2?"  And every character in the game is a terrible person with gallows humor (except for Solaire, he's the best), while some of the monsters are kind of chill.  There were literal times that I laughed out loud at the game and that does not get talked about much.

What I did not enjoy was some of the more dated level traversal aspects.  Like Instant death or just a big waste of time associated with falling from a higher place.  Getting knocked off that higher place happens.  Also, there is no jump button; you have to be running and the press the run button again to do a jump.  In some places this is required.  Heck in the Bed of Chaos boss fight it is required over instant death pits.  Also, rolling and running while locked on is limited.  And some of the achievements are literally RNG based.  Overall I felt like this game was worth playing and finishing, but not something I'm going to be chasing everything in.

Dark Souls is a bad game to me which is really disappointing because of ll the hours I spent experimenting with the games systems and weapon variety. But first lets get bulk of why I think this game is bad, all the bugs, now I don't know how FromSoft got away with simply re-releasing the same so it could keep a £40 price tag but that';s what they did. Going back 7 years before the original game released the team had a lot more experience and now the time and funding to shine down onto the game giving the love it deserved. Except that obviously never happened and only makes me more mad at the game, nearly every bug stays in this remaster. This is a list of the bugs I have found via my playthroughs or watching other people run this game which could be made a point of "well if you didn't find them it doesn't count" but with this games age there is no way FromSoft couldn't of been made aware of them. Soul duping, chain backstabbing, if the centipede demon grabs you in the left hand corner he instantly dies, luring ceaseless discharge (real boss name) back to the fog to fall to his death weirdly, Ornstein's charge attack, hydra mini-boss will sometimes (seemingly randomly) stay forever in an idle animation, Capra demon skip which is way to long to explain but basically involves clipping out of bounds, Queelag skip also to long but involves death cam abuse, Asylum demon skip which is basically leaving the Asylum but without killing the boss, there are probably more I don't know about but this is what I saw in my time playing. Even looking past the bugs the games layout is just poorly designed being very cryptic to navigate through on first playthroughs to just annoying to get through after because of how long it takes to get to where you need to go. Unlocking shortcuts doesn't solve this issue and good luck finding them without a guide same goes for figuring out what to do, I have no problem figuring things out for myself but this isn't an exploration game and trying to solve the old-English npc's does my head in. I'd recommend watching a metric ton of videos on Dark Souls and not go to the wiki as it's just plain terrible (and sometimes wrong), to access the dlc area you have to reload the game 3 times beat half of the game then go back to the other half of the map. Whilst we are on the topic of design who exactly made these hitboxes and were they blind? Now I have no specific examples of this because I like to remember better things but my favourite moments would be lingering hitboxes, when my sword goes visibly through an enemy but does no damage and vice versa. There should have also been basic quality of life features here that where even in later FromSoft titles such as the ability to teleport between bonfires and fast climb ladders, doesn't sound important but Blight Town is almost exclusively ladders and there are some big ones else where like the hydra area. That's just why the game is bad as a remaster though so lets start with the opening tutorial and how it barely teaches the player. Admittedly if you are someone who has never picked up a controller before it does a decent job however I actually play videogames which is why I can't understand why the game never brings up equip loads. That effects your i-frames (obviously important) and in honesty in 80 hours playing the game I still don't really understand the scaling of weapon ratings. What is really annoying to me is how the game teaches you something wrongly, that is the importance of the plunging attack which past the tutorial and first boss you will never really get the chance to use but is made to seem important by the fact it does overwhelming damage to the Asylum demon. Here it also fails to mention what the stats but in fairness does a little but it would be nice to know that before I chose my character and weapon upgrades which is single handily why you can see the health bar move, but hey just figure it out right. At least there are a good variety of playstyles even if the combat is super slow playing out more like a turnbased game which makes me want to pull my hair out (really slow fighting). If you're  coward you can do sorceries or be a pyromancer and if you want to do 0 damage and hit nothing you can do a dex build. Getting my guy dripped out is actually where 90% of my fun lied with and the rest being from when the game wasn't tweaking out. You can make yourself look really cool and there are armour pieces for any kind of character you cook up or imagine lore for which helps with the rpg aspect. Enemies are everywhere on the map but respawn when you die and because I, as you can clearly tell, value my time always walked around and never grinded because neither of those are fun especially with the clippy hitboxes and some playthroughs having low poise. What's poise? Well play the game and find- oh yea it doesn't explain that either. I'll tell you this now walking back to a boss isn't fun and will never be (eventually FromSoft would figured that out) but what grinds my estus flasks are how I'm killing genuine god of death and dragons but when 3 rats jump me it spells instant death (stunlocking bs). Demons, centaur spider witches, massive murderous magma centipede, things that you have to kill yet I lose to the power of five guys, that's because of what I mentioned earlier poise which instead of being tied to armour should be based on resistance giving it a use while still making sense. This makes you funnel your level up points even more into endurance making every playthrough stats look the same, level vitality and endurance while putting points into your damaging stat with only magic runs slightly differing by putting points into attunement. I actually liked this samey feel as it made planning my runs a lot easier and because of how linear the game is. Not to say that traversal was easy as despite the shortcuts it will still take longer than you could ever want it to be to go anywhere, on my 4th run these ended up being counter intuitive as I no longer could remember how to go anywhere without them. I will never admit this to be fault as I am constantly conditioned into using them to save time, instead of having a progressive map constantly leading to new areas you have a spaghetti map where you keep having to backtrack through previously visited areas which is why I could no longer remember the original route. It's actually rather funny how despite all the bosses I ended up killing the hardest part was navigating this map especially on my first playthrough. At the very least these areas look different from each other and I was a fan of the variety between levels and boss designs, I think the concept behind Blight town and how it looks visually is very appealing it's just I could never really appreciate them as I always still bitter over the last 3 deaths eg where a guy hit my through a wall and knocked me down to my death. Then there are boss runs which FromSoft have basically admitted themselves that they're bad by removing them in Elden Ring, no one will ever like these and are just anti-consumer bs there to pad the game. Some can get lost in thought about what this world was like while exploring as you are left with only your thoughts from there being no background music, but that's boring so I played my own. Just because you can't convey your story doesn't mean I need to do that for you and the world didn't interest me enough to look past the surface of it. It is also really jarring going from peace serenity to holier than thou god smite thee, that's what the boss music is like and I do think the music itself is cool the game just doesn't build to it and never felt earned. Though the sound design is, nearly every object breaks and makes it' own sound effect, when you rest at the bonfire there is this soothing voice, running waterfall, etc the devs clearly had passion for this game and that's why I'm disappointed because there is clearly a driven team that works on this.

This is the eptiome of the series! It's crazy that the first installment is the best one, or at least in my opinion. The difficulty is challenging, but not too much like DS2, and is incredibly rewarding to finally beat that spot or boss you were stuck on. The weapons and armor are pretty great (DS3 does have better of both) and the level design is top notch, literally the whole map is connected into one giant map and areas connect back to each other! I haven't seen level design like this anywhere else and it's very impressive to me (literally the biggest factor to why this one is my number one with DS3 being a very close second). I love a good dark fantasy world and Dark Souls really scratches that itch for me. I definitely recommend this game, however if you want to ease into the Souls/Borne series, start with DS3 then come back to this one and if you really enjoyed them, torture yourself with DS2 (Bloodborne plays like DS3 but faster so for some that is an easier start). Finally, I give this game an 11 out of 10, I fucking love this game it is one of my all time favorites!

Coming from someone who started their Souls journey with Elden Ring, I like it so far. 
It definitely takes more to get used to the gameplay and the humanity mechanic involved with it. Dark Souls definitely has less QOL features introduced later in the series and has a bit more of a focus on the game as a whole being difficult rather than the bosses. You need to be careful about where you go and explore areas for every advantage you can get--it's not as easy as picking up a club and spamming your dodge through everything.
Some complaints about the game I might have (longer runs to boss rooms, no multi-directional rolling, etc) are ones that are fixed later in the series anyhow, so I can't really go out and shit on the game for that when it's mainly because it was Fromsoft's second time making a game like this (and apparently Demon Souls sucks).
This game isn't for everyone, but to me, it's one of the best game ever made!!

Things I liked:
-the story

Things I didn't like:

I'd give this game a 9/10. Honestly, I really liked Dark Souls: Remastered. I liked it so much that I decided to get every single achievement in it. I really do not recommend doing that because some achievements are just a pain to keep track of. Thankfully, this game has cloud saving, so you can easily play this on your steam deck whenever you want. I am only mentioning this because Dark Souls 2 and Dark Souls 3 are both lacking cloud saves. This isn't the definitive edition of Dark Souls. Don't let that bother you. There really isn't any definitive edition of Dark Souls, the previous versions were pretty glitchy and had horrible performance in certain sections. This version fixes a lot of the glitches, however there are some new glitches introduced. Even if this game fixed all of those glitches, it still wouldn't be perfect. Some bosses are poorly balanced and really aren't as hard as they should be. Gwyn and Pinwheel are extremely easy despite being later on in the game.

This game, and really all of FromSoft's Souls-Borne games have caused a plethora of YouTube videos and reddit posts titled things like "Dark Souls Saved Me", "How Dark Souls Saved My Life", "Dark Souls Changed My Life" etc for a very good reason. People often say that after playing one of the Souls games, they can never look at any other video game the same again. I don't care who you are or what you've heard about these games, if you are currently, or have ever, experienced any kind of depression, play these games - this one in particular I'd suggest. I highly recommend the video essay "How Souls Games Save You" by Daryl Talks Games, it delves into the psychology of this video game phenomenon and makes me emotional every watch by the end of it. Miyazaki and his team have created absolute artworks with these games, masterpieces, I'd go as far as saying even with their unique flaws. Play the Souls games - even Dark Souls 2 - die, fuck up, make a mistake, die again, fail, die again, and again, and again and again and again, then learn, overcome, grow, and most importantly:

Don't you dare go hollow.

The last in the series to follow the Demon's Souls formula of just trying new things. This is the canvas for every other FromSoftware game, unfortunately for the worst. With FromSoftware being more and more concerned with action gameplay, they've lost the soul of their design. Every boss offers something different; nothing is stagnant here, even in the worst bosses such as bed of chaos, I'd take that a million times over the infinite stamina, 90% of screen spamming bosses of Bloodborne and Elden Ring. While those games are still good, they completely lose focus of what this series really was, playing with conventions. We've played these games for years now and every new game is completely stagnant conceptually. I wish From would return to playing with their game design again. Bosses that question our morality such as Sif, exploration that actually punishes us with traps that can lead to instant death with a long and punishing checkpoint, these things make the game actually hard and more fun to overcome, not just some attack spamming boss.

Dark Souls is a classic game that I decided to finally try.

Often when I complained about the difficulty of a game, I was told that the game was inspired by the difficulty of Dark Souls.

At some point it seemed to me that if I completed Dark Souls, I would get the key to passing other difficult games.

So what is Dark Souls about? This is not a difficult game. There are very few truly difficult parts here at all. But this is an unfair and inconvenient game. The game constantly deprives you of comfort, comes up with inconvenient rules to make you curse. All forces are thrown against the player, so you should not expect any heroic adventures and fair 1 on 1 battles. The goal of the game is to humiliate the player so that he throws away all honor and valor, and also begins to play dishonestly, using every opportunity to win.

Enemies in the distance? I'd rather shoot them with a bow. Do your enemies fight painfully? I will wrap myself in the strongest armor and upgrade my shield. Is there a gorge nearby? I will lure the enemies there.

And once you understand this philosophy, the game becomes trivial.

The worst enemy is distance. If you think this is a fighting game, then you are mistaken. This is a walking simulator. You will go through each path of this game at least a couple of dozen times. The first ten - after death, the second ten - collecting secrets in the surrounding area.

The strongest boss is the one whose path is the longest and most difficult. The easiest boss is the boss where you are resurrected after death.

Do some games say they're hard because they want to be like Dark Souls? Fools, this only means that they will cause you discomfort.

But the game definitely deserves attention. There is a huge world here that is incredibly interesting to explore.
